narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan
narrative.project_title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project titled "NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants" anticipates generating several types of scientific data. These include demographic and clinical data (in tabular form) collected from 110 affected youth and 110 matched healthy controls, as well as various MRI-based imaging data such as structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS. Additionally, derived imaging measures and features will be computed from the raw imaging data. The total volume of data is expected to be substantial, with the imaging data component being the largest. Specifically, participant-level clinical/demographic tables for 220 participants and multi-modal MRI imaging data are anticipated.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected demographic, clinical, and MRI imaging data will be preserved and shared. The rationale behind this decision is to facilitate transparency, reproducibility, and further research in the field by providing a comprehensive dataset that can be used by other researchers. Sharing these data aligns with the principles of openness and collaboration, potentially leading to new insights and discoveries that could benefit public health.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To ensure the interpretability and usability of the shared scientific data, several types of metadata and documentation will be made accessible. These include:
- Data dictionaries that describe the variables and their meanings within the demographic and clinical datasets.
- Protocols used for MRI data acquisition to facilitate understanding of the imaging parameters and procedures.
- README files accompanying each dataset to provide an overview, including information on how the data were collected, processed, and any specific instructions for use.
- Study instruments and questionnaires used for collecting demographic and clinical data.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
Specialized tools and software are needed to access or manipulate the shared scientific data, particularly for the MRI imaging data. These include:
- MRI analysis software such as FSL (FMRIB Software Library) or AFNI (Analysis of Functional NeuroImages) for processing and analyzing fMRI and structural MRI data.
- Spectral analysis software like LCModel or TARQUIN for analyzing 1H fMRS data.
- Statistical software such as R or Python libraries (e.g., Pandas, NumPy, SciPy) for analyzing demographic and clinical data.
These tools are widely used in the neuroimaging community and can be accessed through their respective websites or repositories.

To ensure interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. Specifically:
- The Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) standard will be used for organizing and describing MRI imaging data, facilitating its sharing and analysis.
- For demographic and clinical data, standards such as those provided by the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Data Archive (NDA) will be followed to ensure consistency and comparability across studies.
- Data dictionaries will adhere to standardized formats to enable easy understanding and integration of the data.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), a repository that specializes in housing data related to mental health research. The NDA provides a secure and accessible platform for sharing data, facilitating collaboration among researchers.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: The scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the use of persistent unique identifiers. Each participant's data will be associated with a global unique identifier (GUID) generated according to NDA guidelines, ensuring that data can be linked across different studies while maintaining participant confidentiality.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available to other users no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data are expected to remain available for at least 10 years following the completion of the project to allow for extended research and analysis opportunities.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: While maximizing data sharing is a priority, considerations related to informed consent, privacy, and confidentiality protections may limit the extent of data sharing. Specifically, all data will be deidentified prior to sharing to protect participant privacy. However, because participants have been consented for broad data sharing, these limitations are anticipated to be minimal.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will not be controlled beyond the standard procedures implemented by the NDA for data access and sharing. Researchers will be able to access the data upon registration with the NDA and agreement to its terms of use.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, all shared data will be deidentified. This includes removing direct identifiers (e.g., names, addresses) and indirect identifiers that could potentially reveal participant identities. Additionally, the use of Certificates of Confidentiality, where applicable, will further safeguard against disclosure of sensitive information.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the project's Principal Investigator (PI) in collaboration with the institution's data management office. Regular checks (at least bi-annually) will be performed to ensure that data are being collected, stored, and shared according to the plan. The PI will also be responsible for ensuring that all team members are aware of and adhere to the data sharing policies and procedures outlined in this plan. Any deviations or issues related to data management and sharing will be addressed promptly and reported as necessary to the funding agency and institutional oversight bodies.
